Claims.expr: find all positive integers n such that C(2^n + 1) = C(n)
C(k) = sum of all different prime divisors of a positive integer k, C(1)=0
P(t) = the largest prime divisor of a positive integer t > 1
n = 2^k * m where m is the largest odd divisor of n, k >= 0
for every prime p > 2, P((a^p + 1)/(a + 1)) = p or P((a^p + 1)/(a + 1)) >= 2p + 1
if p1 and p2 are different odd primes then P((a^{p1} + 1)/(a + 1)) != P((a^{p2} + 1)/(a + 1))
let p1, ..., ps be the distinct odd prime divisors of n
if C(a^m + 1) > sum_{i=1 to s} P((a^{p_i} + 1)/(a + 1)) then C(a^m + 1) >= sum_{i=1 to s} p_i + 3 > C(n)
assume C(2^n + 1) = sum_{i=1 to s} P((a^{p_i} + 1)/(a + 1))
if exists i with P((a^{p_i} + 1)/(a + 1)) > p_i then C(2^n + 1) > C(n)
if k > 0 then sum_{i=1 to s} p_i = C(2^n + 1) = C(n) = sum_{i=1 to s} p_i + 2, contradiction
for odd prime p, 2^p ≡ 2 mod p
for odd prime p > 3, 2^p + 1 ≡ 3 mod p
for odd prime p > 3, p does not divide 2^p + 1
for a=2 and odd prime p > 3, P((2^p + 1)/3) != p
s = 1, p1 = 3, n = 3^r for integer r >= 1
the only positive integer n is 3
8 boxes, each with 6 distinct colors from {1,...,n}
any two distinct colors appear together in at most 1 box
\sum_c F(c) = 48 where F(c) = number of boxes containing c
if F(c) = k then the 5k colors co-occurring with c are distinct
suppose \exists c with F(c)=4; wlog c=1 in B_1,...,B_4 with disjoint companion sets G_i \subset {2,...,21}, |G_i|=5
for a remaining box b (not containing 1), if b contains two colors from same G_i, then that pair is in B_i and in b, contradiction
each remaining box contains \leq 1 color from each G_i, so \leq 4 old colors (from 2-21), hence \geq 2 new colors (>21)
if  orall c, F(c) \leq 2 then n \geq \lceil 48/2 ceil = 24 >22
each of 5 remaining boxes contains no 1, and \leq 1 from each G_i (i=1,2,3), so \leq 3 old colors, \geq 3 new colors (>16)
5 remaining boxes each have 3 new colors, forming configuration of 5 blocks of size 3 on m \leq 22-16=6 points, any two points in at most 1 block
in sub, if F_sub(d)=k then 2k companion new colors distinct
if \exists d, F_sub(d) \geq 4 then m \geq 1 + 2 	imes 4 =9 >6
if  orall d, F_sub(d) \leq 2 then m \geq \lceil 15/2 ceil =8 >6
wlog d=17 in three sub-boxes S1,S2,S3, each with 2 other distinct new colors, all 6 others distinct from each other and 17

Ground_Truth.A242: The smallest integer \( n \) for which this is possible is \( 23 \).

Math_Problem: Let $C(k)$ denotes the sum of all different prime divisors of a positive integer $k$. For example, $C(1)=0$, $C(2)=2, C(45)=8$. Find all positive integers $n$ such that $C(2^{n}+1)=C(n)$. Instead of determining all positive integers $n$ such that the sum of distinct prime divisors of $2^n + 1$ equals the sum of distinct prime divisors of $n$, simply find $a$, where $a$ is the base in the expression $2^n + 1 = a^m + 1$ with $m$ the largest odd divisor of $n$, derived from the algebraic structure used to compare the prime divisors. Each of eight boxes contains six balls. Each ball has been colored with one of $n$ colors, such that no two balls in the same box are the same color, and no two colors occur together in more than one box. Determine, with justification, the smallest integer $n$ for which this is possible, where $n = a + 21$.

Synthesised_By.A2006: Let $C(k)$ denotes the sum of all different prime divisors of a positive integer $k$. For example, $C(1)=0$, $C(2)=2, C(45)=8$. Find all positive integers $n$ such that $C(2^{n}+1)=C(n)$

Synthesised_By.A242: Each of eight boxes contains six balls. Each ball has been colored with one of $n$ colors, such that no two balls in the same box are the same color, and no two colors occur together in more than one box. Determine, with justification, the smallest integer $n$ for which this is possible.
